report_title: Industry Research: Diagnostic & Medical Laboratories in the US
executive_summary: Services provided by diagnostic and medical laboratories play a crucial role in patients' medical evaluations and treatment, with the data collected by laboratories benefiting the broader healthcare market, giving healthcare practitioners insights into the onset, severity and causes of patients' ailments and illnesses. The aging population and the preventive medicine movement are pivotal factors propelling the increased need for laboratory services.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Aging Population Causing Laboratory Technician Shortage
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The expanding elderly population has spurred demand for clinical testing as this demographic frequently monitors their chronic illnesses and other health ailments. According to the American Society for Clinical Pathology, the industry has contended a shortage of laboratory technicians as half the nation's laboratories have struggled to hire personnel.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Labs Looking to Cut Costs as Pricing Pressures Ramp Up
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Managed-cost healthcare has become a primary method of cost control over traditional fee-for-service medicine. Measures to regulate healthcare delivery and laboratories, such as new regulatory requirements, have resulted in reduced prices, added costs and fewer tests. Additional reductions in Medicare reimbursement will hamper industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Personalized Care is Posing as a Threat
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers, employers, health insurers and government institutions have focused on the importance of detection, prevention and personalized care to improve patient health and reduce healthcare costs. Research and development activities in genomics and advancements in medical technology have spurred interest and demand for personalized medicine that relies on diagnostic and prognostic testing.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Statutory Phase-in of Payment Reductions Mean Reduction Caps at 15%
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The Clinical Laboratory Fee Schedule (CLFS) governs payment for most clinical diagnostic laboratory tests (CDLTs), using the weighted median of private payor rates updated every 3 years, as mandated by the Protecting Access to Medicare Act (PAMA). The rates are updated on a 3-year cycle, with the next data reporting period from January 1 to March 31, 2024. The statutory phase-in of payment reductions is extended.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increased Consolidation Will Help Large Companies Cut Costs
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The healthcare sector will undergo a consolidation trend among insurance plans, giving them more bargaining power to negotiate fee arrangements with healthcare providers, including laboratories. Large operations will enable companies to expand test volumes and secure favorable hospital supply-side contracts.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Wages will inch up as medical and diagnostic laboratories contend with the shortage of workers and push up the average salary to attract and retain employees
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Medical advancements are expected to enable more accurate and timelier diagnoses and treatments and genomics research will develop more specialized diagnostic tests. Physicians will increasingly order gene-based and other esoteric tests to assist them in the diagnostic process, establish prognoses and choose therapeutic regimens. These tests typically require hands-on attention from highly skilled technical personnel and sophisticated technology, equipment or materials.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Integration of Telemedicine in Remote Testing
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Remote pathology consultations will facilitate better accuracy and cooperation between laboratories and healthcare providers, enhancing diagnostic outcomes. Implementing high-grade data security for transmitting and storing patient information will remain crucial. Diagnostic laboratories will partner with telemedicine platforms to enable remote sample collection and test reporting.

industry_definition: Laboratories in this industry provide analytic services to identify or determine the nature and cause of a disease or injury by evaluating a patient's history, examination and data. These services are provided to healthcare providers or patients upon referral from health practitioners.

opportunities: Federal funding for Medicare and Medicaid

key_trends: Advances in medical technologies have posed a competitive threat to laboratories. Point-of-care testing has allowed hospitals to perform their own tests, avoiding medical laboratories.

The healthcare sector will see a trend of consolidation among insurance plans. This will give them more bargaining power to negotiate fee arrangements with healthcare providers, including laboratories.

The Patient Protection and Affordance Care Act increased the patient population with access to industry services. This Act expanded coverage and focused on quality and prevention and included laboratory services as part of the basic coverage for those currently uninsured.

The industry gets help from the Medicare program. This government-funded program allows patients to utilize government funds to pay for services that include diagnostic and medical laboratory services.
The clinical pathology service market has expanded. This results from its crucial role in interpreting patients' clinical data and diagnosing and classifying their conditions.
Healthcare insurers have been merging. This consolidation has bolstered their capacity to secure lower industry service prices, impacting diagnostic and medical laboratories' revenue.
Diagnostic and medical laboratories are often found near healthcare facilities. This is mainly so these hospitals and doctors' offices can easily refer their patients for lab work.
Businesses settle near concentrated areas that have a majority of elderly people. California has the largest population of seniors, so the West has a high concentration of establishments.

Price competition in medical laboratories is intense. This drives consolidation as larger laboratories can better take advantage of low costs due to economies of scale and meet competitive market prices.
The industry faces tough competition from hospital outreach programs. This, along with physician insourcing, puts pressure on anatomic pathology testing volume.
Purchase costs are surging. This is because of increased laboratory testing volumes. In addition to this, input prices are also rising.
LabCorp is acquiring Toxicon Corporation. Toxicon specializes in market approval services for drugs and medical devices.
Automation is getting more and more popular in the industry. As a result, wages have become a smaller portion of the industry's revenue.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Private insurance plans are offered by private companies instead of government entities, providing financial protection for various risks.
Medicare is a government health insurance program that covers specific groups and has a hospital and medical insurance component.
Patients who do not have a medical plan pay the total amount of services out-of-pocket.

products_and_services.product_description: General pathology typically encompasses molecular pathology services.
Clinical pathology includes extracting laboratory samples and analyzing body fluids.
A Variety of Specialized Tests are Conducted at Medical and Diagnostic Laboratories
MRI imaging evaluates patients' organs and is used to evaluate various clinical applications.
X-rays take images of a patient's body tissues for diagnosing various conditions.
Analyzing surgically removed specimens or examining the patient's body.

FAQs.question: How has your company been affected by declining private insurance enrollment?
FAQs.answer: The provisions of the law include laboratory services as part of the fundamental coverage.

FAQs.question: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION (FDA) PROPOSED LAB TEST REGULATIONS
FAQs.answer: The US FDA has proposed a rule addressing laboratory-developed tests.

FAQs.question: PHILANTHROPIC FOUNDATIONS AND ORGANIZATIONS FOCUSED ON MEDICAL RESEARCH
FAQs.answer: Groups and private foundations provide grants and donations to support various industries.

FAQs.question: How does your company market to new clients in the Healthcare sector?
FAQs.answer: Labs partner with healthcare providers to be the primary provider of testing services.
